Data Retrieval Queries.title: Retrieve All Records from Employees Table
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Write a SQL query to retrieve all records from the employees table.
hints: Use SELECT * to return all rows.
Make sure you reference the correct table name.
Data Retrieval Queries.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, department TEXT, salary INTEGER);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice Johnson', 'HR', 60000),
(2, 'Bob Smith', 'Engineering', 90000),
(3, 'Catherine Lee', 'Finance', 75000),
(4, 'David Kim', 'Engineering', 85000),
(5, 'Emma Davis', 'Marketing', 65000),
(6, 'Frank Moore', 'Finance', 72000),
(7, 'Grace Hall', 'HR', 58000),
(8, 'Henry Clark', 'Marketing', 63000);

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Select Employee Names and Departments
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Write a query to return each employee's name and department.
hints: Select only name and department fields.

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Retrieve Products with Price Greater Than 100
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Write a query to fetch all products priced greater than 100.
Data Retrieval Queries.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE products(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, price INTEGER);
INSERT INTO products VALUES
(1, 'Laptop Bag', 80),
(2, 'Keyboard', 120),
(3, 'Monitor', 250),
(4, 'USB Cable', 15),
(5, 'Headphones', 180);

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Get All Orders Placed on 2024-01-10
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Write a SQL query to return all orders placed on '2024-01-10'.
hints: Use a date filter in WHERE.

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Select All Customers Not from Canada
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Write a SQL query to return all customers who are not from Canada.

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Retrieve Employees Hired After 2022
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Write a query to fetch employees hired after the year 2022.

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Fetch Items Containing 'SQL' in Name
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Return all items whose name contains the substring 'SQL'.
Data Retrieval Queries.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM items WHERE name LIKE '%SQL%';

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Retrieve In-Stock Products
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Write a query to fetch all products that have more than 0 stock.

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Select Employees from Engineering Department
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Retrieve all employees who work in the Engineering department.

Data Retrieval Queries.title: Retrieve Customers Whose Name Starts With 'A'
Data Retrieval Queries.description: Write a query to return customers whose name starts with the letter 'A'.
Data Retrieval Queries.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE customers(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT);
INSERT INTO customers VALUES
(1, 'Alice'),
(2, 'Amanda'),
(3, 'Bob'),
(4, 'Chris'),
(5, 'Arjun');
Data Retrieval Queries.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM customers WHERE name LIKE 'A%';

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Get Unique Countries from Customers
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a SQL query to return all unique countries from the customers table.
hints: Use DISTINCT to eliminate duplicate country names.
Filtering and Sorting Data.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE customers(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, country TEXT);
INSERT INTO customers VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 'USA'),
(2, 'Bob', 'Canada'),
(3, 'Charlie', 'USA'),
(4, 'David', 'Germany'),
(5, 'Emma', 'Canada'),
(6, 'Frank', 'India');

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Top 5 Highest-Paid Employees
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a SQL query to return the top 5 employees with the highest salary.
hints: Sort by salary in descending order.
Filtering and Sorting Data.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, salary INTEGER);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 60000),
(2, 'Bob', 90000),
(3, 'Charlie', 75000),
(4, 'David', 85000),
(5, 'Emma', 65000),
(6, 'Frank', 72000),
(7, 'Grace', 58000),
(8, 'Henry', 95000);
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY salary DESC LIMIT 5;

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Products Priced Between 50 and 200
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a query to fetch all products whose price is between 50 and 200.
hints: Use the BETWEEN keyword with inclusive bounds.
Filtering and Sorting Data.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE products(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, price INTEGER);
INSERT INTO products VALUES
(1, 'USB Cable', 15),
(2, 'Keyboard', 120),
(3, 'Monitor', 250),
(4, 'Mouse', 45),
(5, 'Headphones', 180),
(6, 'Laptop Stand', 75);
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM products WHERE price BETWEEN 50 AND 200;

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Retrieve Employees Aged 25 to 35
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a query to select employees whose age is between 25 and 35.
hints: Age range filters commonly use BETWEEN.
Filtering and Sorting Data.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, age INTEGER);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 22),
(2, 'Bob', 28),
(3, 'Charlie', 35),
(4, 'David', 41),
(5, 'Emma', 31),
(6, 'Frank', 26);
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE age BETWEEN 25 AND 35;

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Employees in Selected Departments
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a query to return employees working in either Engineering, HR, or Finance.
hints: Use the IN keyword for multiple matches.
Filtering and Sorting Data.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, department TEXT);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 'Engineering'),
(2, 'Bob', 'Marketing'),
(3, 'Charlie', 'Finance'),
(4, 'David', 'HR'),
(5, 'Emma', 'Sales');
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM employees WHERE department IN ('Engineering', 'HR', 'Finance');

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Sort Products by Price (Descending)
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a query to sort all products by price in descending order.
Filtering and Sorting Data.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE products(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, price INTEGER);
INSERT INTO products VALUES
(1, 'USB Cable', 15),
(2, 'Keyboard', 120),
(3, 'Monitor', 250),
(4, 'Mouse', 45),
(5, 'Headphones', 180);
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM products ORDER BY price DESC;

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Sort Employees Alphabetically by Name
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a query to return employees sorted alphabetically by their name.
hints: Sorting of text columns uses ORDER BY name ASC.
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY name ASC;

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Retrieve the 3 Cheapest Products
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a query to return the 3 products with the lowest price.
hints: Sort ascending and limit to 3 rows.
Filtering and Sorting Data.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE products(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, price INTEGER);
INSERT INTO products VALUES
(1, 'Laptop', 900),
(2, 'Mouse', 20),
(3, 'Keyboard', 40),
(4, 'USB Cable', 10),
(5, 'Monitor', 200);
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM products ORDER BY price ASC LIMIT 3;

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Customers Not Aged Between 30 and 50
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a query to return all customers who are NOT between ages 30 and 50.
hints: Use NOT BETWEEN for the negation.
Filtering and Sorting Data.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE customers(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, age INTEGER);
INSERT INTO customers VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 25),
(2, 'Bob', 32),
(3, 'Charlie', 51),
(4, 'David', 29),
(5, 'Emma', 48);
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM customers WHERE age NOT BETWEEN 30 AND 50;

Filtering and Sorting Data.title: Return Rows 6 to 8 from Employees Table
Filtering and Sorting Data.description: Write a query to skip the first 5 employee records and return the next 3.
hints: Order the results to ensure consistency.
Filtering and Sorting Data.solutionSQL: SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY id LIMIT 3 OFFSET 5;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Count Total Number of Employees
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a SQL query to count the total number of employees.
hints: Use COUNT(*) to count all rows.
COUNT(id) also works if id is never NULL.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, department TEXT);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 'HR'),
(2, 'Bob', 'Engineering'),
(3, 'Charlie', 'Finance'),
(4, 'David', 'Engineering'),
(5, 'Emma', 'Marketing');
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT COUNT(*) AS total_employees FROM employees;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Find Maximum Employee Salary
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a SQL query to return the highest salary from the employees table.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, salary INTEGER);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 60000),
(2, 'Bob', 80000),
(3, 'Charlie', 75000),
(4, 'David', 90000),
(5, 'Emma', 65000);
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT MAX(salary) AS highest_salary FROM employees;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Find Minimum Product Price
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a query to return the lowest product price.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE products(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, price INTEGER);
INSERT INTO products VALUES
(1, 'Laptop', 900),
(2, 'Keyboard', 40),
(3, 'Mouse', 25),
(4, 'USB Cable', 10),
(5, 'Monitor', 250);
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT MIN(price) AS lowest_price FROM products;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Calculate Average Order Amount
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a SQL query to calculate the average order amount.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT AVG(amount) AS average_amount FROM orders;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Calculate Total Revenue from Orders
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a SQL query to calculate the total revenue from all orders.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT SUM(amount) AS total_revenue FROM orders;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Count Employees in Finance Department
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a SQL query to count employees who belong to the Finance department.
hints: Use COUNT(*) with a WHERE condition.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT COUNT(*) AS finance_count FROM employees WHERE department = 'Finance';

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Find Average Salary by Department
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a SQL query to return the average salary for each department.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, department TEXT, salary INTEGER);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 'HR', 60000),
(2, 'Bob', 'Engineering', 90000),
(3, 'Charlie', 'Engineering', 85000),
(4, 'David', 'Finance', 75000),
(5, 'Emma', 'HR', 62000);
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT department, AVG(salary) AS avg_salary FROM employees GROUP BY department;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Find Highest and Lowest Order Amount
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a SQL query to return the highest and lowest order amount.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT MIN(amount) AS lowest_amount, MAX(amount) AS highest_amount FROM orders;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Count Products Priced Above 100
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a query to count how many products have a price greater than 100.
hints: Use COUNT(*) with a WHERE filter.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT COUNT(*) AS product_count FROM products WHERE price > 100;

Aggregation and Summary Functions.title: Sum Salaries of Engineering Employees
Aggregation and Summary Functions.description: Write a SQL query to calculate the total salary of all employees in the Engineering department.
hints: Use SUM(salary) with a WHERE filter for department.
Aggregation and Summary Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT SUM(salary) AS total_salary FROM employees WHERE department = 'Engineering';

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Count Employees in Each Department
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to count how many employees work in each department.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, department TEXT);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 'HR'),
(2, 'Bob', 'Engineering'),
(3, 'Charlie', 'Engineering'),
(4, 'David', 'Finance'),
(5, 'Emma', 'HR');
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT department, COUNT(*) AS employee_count FROM employees GROUP BY department;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Total Sales per Store
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to calculate total sales amount for each store.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE sales(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, store_id INTEGER, amount INTEGER);
INSERT INTO sales VALUES
(1, 1, 200),
(2, 1, 150),
(3, 2, 400),
(4, 2, 100),
(5, 3, 500);
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT store_id, SUM(amount) AS total_sales FROM sales GROUP BY store_id;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Average Salary per Job Role
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to calculate the average salary for each job role.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, job_role TEXT, salary INTEGER);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 'Developer', 80000),
(2, 'Bob', 'Developer', 90000),
(3, 'Charlie', 'Manager', 120000),
(4, 'David', 'Manager', 110000),
(5, 'Emma', 'Designer', 70000);
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT job_role, AVG(salary) AS avg_salary FROM employees GROUP BY job_role;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Count Orders per Month
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to count how many orders were placed in each month.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE orders(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, order_date TEXT);
INSERT INTO orders VALUES
(1, '2024-01-05'),
(2, '2024-01-20'),
(3, '2024-02-11'),
(4, '2024-02-28'),
(5, '2024-03-02');
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT strftime('%m', order_date) AS month, COUNT(*) AS order_count FROM orders GROUP BY month;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Departments with More Than 2 Employees
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to return departments that have more than 2 employees.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE employees(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, department TEXT);
INSERT INTO employees VALUES
(1, 'Alice', 'HR'),
(2, 'Bob', 'Engineering'),
(3, 'Charlie', 'Engineering'),
(4, 'David', 'Engineering'),
(5, 'Emma', 'HR');
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT department, COUNT(*) AS employee_count FROM employees GROUP BY department HAVING COUNT(*) > 2;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Total Hours Worked per Employee
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to calculate the total hours worked by each employee.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE work_logs(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, employee_id INTEGER, hours INTEGER);
INSERT INTO work_logs VALUES
(1, 1, 5),
(2, 1, 3),
(3, 2, 8),
(4, 2, 6),
(5, 3, 4);
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT employee_id, SUM(hours) AS total_hours FROM work_logs GROUP BY employee_id;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Count Customers per Country
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to count how many customers belong to each country.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT country, COUNT(*) AS customer_count FROM customers GROUP BY country;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Total Revenue per Product Category
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a query to calculate total revenue generated for each product category.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE products(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, category TEXT, price INTEGER);
INSERT INTO products VALUES
(1, 'Laptop', 'Electronics', 900),
(2, 'Mouse', 'Electronics', 20),
(3, 'Shirt', 'Clothing', 40),
(4, 'Jeans', 'Clothing', 60),
(5, 'Book', 'Books', 25);
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT category, SUM(price) AS total_revenue FROM products GROUP BY category;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Order Status with More Than 2 Orders
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to return order statuses that appear more than 2 times.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE orders(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, status TEXT);
INSERT INTO orders VALUES
(1, 'Pending'),
(2, 'Shipped'),
(3, 'Shipped'),
(4, 'Delivered'),
(5, 'Shipped'),
(6, 'Pending');
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT status, COUNT(*) AS status_count FROM orders GROUP BY status HAVING COUNT(*) > 2;

Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.title: Average Rating per Product (Above 4)
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.description: Write a SQL query to calculate the average rating for each product and return only those products whose average rating is greater than 4.
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.setupSQL:
CREATE TABLE reviews(id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, product_id INTEGER, rating INTEGER);
INSERT INTO reviews VALUES
(1, 1, 5),
(2, 1, 4),
(3, 1, 5),
(4, 2, 3),
(5, 2, 4),
(6, 3, 5);
Grouping and Conditional Aggregation.solutionSQL: SELECT product_id, AVG(rating) AS avg_rating FROM reviews GROUP BY product_id HAVING AVG(rating) > 4;

Introductory Joins.title: Inner Join Employees with Departments
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return employee names along with their department names using an INNER JOIN.
hints: INNER JOIN returns only matching rows.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT e.name AS employee_name, d.name AS department_name FROM employees e INNER JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.id;

Introductory Joins.title: Left Join Customers with Orders
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return all customers and any matching orders using a LEFT JOIN.
hints: LEFT JOIN returns all customers even if they have no orders.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT c.name AS customer_name, o.amount FROM customers c LEFT JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id;

Introductory Joins.title: Right Join Products with Suppliers
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return all suppliers and the products they supply using a RIGHT JOIN.
hints: RIGHT JOIN returns all suppliers even if they have no products.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT p.name AS product_name, s.name AS supplier_name FROM products p RIGHT JOIN suppliers s ON p.supplier_id = s.id;

Introductory Joins.title: Inner Join Orders with Customers
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return order IDs along with the matching customer names.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT o.id AS order_id, c.name AS customer_name FROM orders o INNER JOIN customers c ON o.customer_id = c.id;

Introductory Joins.title: Self Join Employees with Managers
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return each employee along with their manager's name using a self join.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT e.name AS employee_name, m.name AS manager_name FROM employees e LEFT JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.id;

Introductory Joins.title: Inner Join Students with Courses
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to list all students along with the courses they are enrolled in.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT s.name AS student_name, c.title AS course_title FROM students s INNER JOIN courses c ON s.course_id = c.id;

Introductory Joins.title: Left Join Products with Categories
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return all products along with their category names using a LEFT JOIN.
hints: Some products may not belong to any category.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT p.name AS product_name, c.name AS category_name FROM products p LEFT JOIN categories c ON p.category_id = c.id;

Introductory Joins.title: Right Join Tasks with Employees
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return all employees and the tasks assigned to them using a RIGHT JOIN.
hints: Include employees even if they have no tasks.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT t.title AS task_title, e.name AS employee_name FROM tasks t RIGHT JOIN employees e ON t.employee_id = e.id;

Introductory Joins.title: Join Authors with Their Books
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return authors and the books they have written.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT a.name AS author_name, b.title AS book_title FROM authors a INNER JOIN books b ON a.id = b.author_id;

Introductory Joins.title: Find Employees Without Departments
Introductory Joins.description: Write a SQL query to return employees who do not belong to any department.
hints: Use LEFT JOIN then filter department rows that are NULL.
Introductory Joins.solutionSQL: SELECT e.name AS employee_name FROM employees e LEFT JOIN departments d ON e.department_id = d.id WHERE d.id IS NULL;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Display Full Name Using CONCAT
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a SQL query to display each employee's full name using CONCAT and alias the column as full_name.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT CONCAT(first_name, ' ', last_name) AS full_name FROM employees;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Convert Names to Uppercase
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a SQL query to return customer names in uppercase.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT UPPER(name) AS name_upper FROM customers;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Show Length of Product Names
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a query to return each product name and its length.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT name, LENGTH(name) AS name_length FROM products;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Extract First 3 Characters of Employee Names
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a query to return the first three characters of each employee's name.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT SUBSTR(name, 1, 3) AS short_name FROM employees;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Replace Spaces in Item Names With Hyphens
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a SQL query to replace spaces in item names with hyphens '-'.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT REPLACE(name, ' ', '-') AS formatted_name FROM items;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Trim Leading and Trailing Spaces
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a query to trim leading and trailing spaces from product names.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT TRIM(name) AS trimmed_name FROM products;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Show Name and Salary With Aliases
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a SQL query to return employee name as employee_name and salary as monthly_salary.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT name AS employee_name, salary AS monthly_salary FROM employees;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Create a Labeled Salary Category
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a SQL query to display each employee's salary category as 'High', 'Medium', or 'Low' using CASE.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT name, CASE WHEN salary > 70000 THEN 'High' WHEN salary BETWEEN 50000 AND 70000 THEN 'Medium' ELSE 'Low' END AS salary_category FROM employees;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Extract Email Username
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a SQL query to extract the email username (before the '@' symbol).
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT SUBSTR(email, 1, INSTR(email, '@') - 1) AS username FROM users;

Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.title: Combine Name and Department in One Column
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.description: Write a query to display each employee in the format 'Name (Department)'.
Column Aliasing & Core SQL Functions.solutionSQL: SELECT CONCAT(name, ' (', department, ')') AS label FROM employees;
